X.T: Les nombres irrationnels | Voyages au pays des maths | ARTE

X.T: How Do Mathematicians Know Their Proofs Are Correct?
X.ST: What makes a proof stronger than a guess? What does evidence look like in the realm of mathematical abstraction? Hear the mathematician Melanie Matchett Wood explain how probability helps to guide number theorists toward certainty.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: An introduction to the fact that statistics can be used for proofs in number theory.
Heegner number and Ramanujan’s constant.
Some information about the Abbel Prize and Szemerédi’s theorem.
The invention of zero.

Catalan’s Conjecture has been proven by PredaMihăilescu in 2002 and proving that x^2-y^3=1 has no odd solutions.

X.T: Landmark Math Proof Clears Hurdle in Top Erdős Conjecture
X.ST: Two mathematicians have proved the first leg of Paul Erdős’ all-time favorite problem about number patterns.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: ThomasBloom and OlofSisask proved that whenever a number list’s sum of reciprocals is infinite, it must contain infinitely many evenly spaced triples.

X.T: Surprise Computer Science Proof Stuns Mathematicians
X.ST: For decades, mathematicians have been inching forward on a problem about which sets contain evenly spaced patterns of three numbers. Last month, two computer scientists blew past all of those results.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The upper bound of the maximum size of triple-free set has been largely decreased.

X.T: A Chemist Shines Light on a Surprising Prime Number Pattern
X.ST: When a crystallographer treated prime numbers as a system of particles, the resulting diffraction pattern created a new view of existing conjectures in number theory.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The diffraction of prime numbers shows some patterns, but does this have any interest?
Two proofs that 24 divides p^2-1 for any prime greater than 3.

X.T: Big Question About Primes Proved in Small Number Systems
X.ST: The twin primes conjecture is one of the most important and difficult questions in mathematics. Two mathematicians have solved a parallel version of the problem for small number systems.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says it all.

X.T: Why do prime numbers make these spirals? | Dirichlet’s theorem and pi approximations

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Explaining some drawing artefacts with rational approximations of π and Dirichlet’s theorem.
JamesMaynard proved that there is an infinite number or primes without a given digit, but there is no information about the proof.
The Mertens Conjecture has been proven wrong.
906150257 is the smallest counterexample of Pólya conjecture.
Encoding the sequence of primes in a single number.
The continuation of the previous video.
A short history of the primality of one.
A very short and basic presentation of Legendre’s conjecture.
A description of Miller–Rabin primality test, but there is no mathematical explanation of how it works.

X.ST: Decades ago, a mathematician posed a warmup problem for some of the most difficult questions about prime numbers. It turned out to be just as difficult to solve, until now.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: HaraldHelfgott and MaksymRadziwiłł proved the logarithmic Chowla conjecture: the parity of the number of prime factors of an integer is not correlated with that of its neighbours.

X.T: How Can Infinitely Many Primes Be Infinitely Far Apart?
X.ST: Mathematicians have been studying the distribution of prime numbers for thousands of years. Recent results about a curious kind of prime offer a new take on how spread out they can be.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some facts about the density of primes: gaps between primes, digitally delicate primes, and widely digitally delicate primes.

X.T: An Exact Formula for the Primes: Willans' Formula

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A detailed explanation of C. P. Willans’ formula to compute the n-th prime.

X.T: Teenager Solves Stubborn Riddle About Prime Number Look-Alikes
X.ST: In his senior year of high school, Daniel Larsen proved a key theorem about Carmichael numbers — strange entities that mimic the primes. “It would be a paper that any mathematician would be really proud to have written,” said one mathematician.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A 17-years old boy gets some results about the density of Carmichael numbers.
An obviously wrong conjecture about primes.
Farey sequence, Euler’s totient function…
The 4k-1 vs. 4k+1 prime race.

X.T: Why Mathematicians Re-Prove What They Already Know
X.ST: It’s been known for thousands of years that the primes go on forever, but new proofs give fresh insights into how theorems depend on one another.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Using complex mathematical results to prove, once again, that there are infinitely many prime numbers.

X.T: How to Build a Big Prime Number
X.ST: A new algorithm brings together the advantages of randomness and deterministic processes to reliably construct large prime numbers.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some mathematicians found a polynomial-time and pseudodeterministic (producing the same solution with high probability) algorithm to find prime numbers of length n or, more generally, numbers having a property decidable in polynomial time.

X.T: A New Generation of Mathematicians Pushes Prime Number Barriers
X.ST: New work attacks a long-standing barrier to understanding how prime numbers are distributed.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The progess on knowing better the distribution of primes.

X.T: Mathematicians Find a New Class of Digitally Delicate Primes

X.T: Visualizing quaternions (4d numbers) with stereographic projection

X.T: The Strange Numbers That Birthed Modern Algebra
